column4: and with his bludgeon struck many blows on the bed
column5: in the very place where Jack had laid the log; and then he went back to his own room
column6: thinking he had broken all Jack's bones.Early in the morning Jack put a bold face upon the matter and walked into the Giant's room to thank him for his lodging. The Giant started when he saw him
column7: and began to stammer out: "Oh! dear me; is it you? Pray
column8: how did you sleep last night? Did you hear or see anything in the dead of the night?""Nothing worth speaking of
column11: gave me three or four slaps with its tail
column12: and disturbed me a little; but I soon went to sleep again."The Giant wondered more and more at this; yet he did not answer a word
column13: but went to bring two great bowls of hasty-pudding for their breakfast.
